This post is based on the lecture "Computer vision" of professor Kim Seon Ju from Yonsei univ.

<br>

------

`03.26 Tuesday`

## Periodic noise

It is arise due to electrical or electromechanical interference. It is look like a repeating pattern. In the frequency domain, this type of noise can be seen as discrete spikes. By **removing a particular range of frequencies** from that image, noise can be removed. **Band reject filters** are commonly used. 

![Adaptive threshold based frequency domain filter for periodic noise reduction](https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1434841116309414-gr4.jpg)
<a href="<https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1434841116309414>">Adaptive threshold based frequency domain filter for periodic noise reduction</a>

![Band reject filter](https://www.harrisgeospatial.com/docs/html/images/bandreject_filter_ex.gif)
<br>

## Image degradation

Last section, I expressed the degradation model as **convolution with degradation function _h(x,y)_ and add noise**. We had seen noise until now, so let's move on to degradation function. 
The degradation function is convolution. This degradation can occur for many reasons, some typical reasons are here.

> 1. Motion blur
>    camera panning or subject moving
>
> 2. Atmospheric blur
>    long exposure
>
> 3. Uniform 2D blur
>
> 4. Out-of-Focus Blur

![motion blur](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

![atmospheric blur](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

### Non-blind deblurring

If we know *h function*, then we can use **deconvolution**. This is called **inverse filtering**. However *h function* often has zeros, specifically at the high frequencies. So we can often just ignore 0 values, and concentrate on the low-frequencies where H is defined. but this uncertainties have a significant impact. **Anyway, it usually doesn't work well in practical**. (Ringing, making noise more noticeable...)

### Wiener filter

![Wiener filter](http://gael-varoquaux.info/scipy-lecture-notes/_images/sphx_glr_plot_image_filters_001.png)

<br>
